b. For general use. Demonstration or participation program.
FIRST AWARD. "NBC Home Symphony." Broadcast of March 13, 1938. Planned
and produced by the National Broadcasting Company. Written, directed and
conducted by Ernest La Prade. Broadcast March 13, 1938, from 12:00 to
12t30 P.M. over Station WEAF, New York and the NBC Red Net-work.
c. For general use. Dialog, round-table conversation, interview, debate, ques¬
tion and answer.
FIRST AWARD. "Cooperation -with Government." From the series, "America's
To-wn Meeting of the Air." Planned and produced by the National Broad¬
casting Company and To-wn Hall, Inc. Arranged by George Denny, Jr. Dir¬
ected by Joseph Bell. Speakers, Willkie and Jackson, Broadcast January
6, 1938, from 9:30 to 10:30 P.M. over Station WJZ, New York, and the NBC
Blue Network.
d. For general use. All forms of dramatization.
FIRST AWARD. "The House That Jack Didn't Build." From the "Columbia
Workshop" series. Planned and produced by the Columbia Broadcasting
System. Written by Alfred Kreymborg. Directed by William N. Robson
and produced with professional cast. Broadcast January 15, 1938, from
8:00 to 8:30 P.M. over Station WABC, New York, and the CBS Network.
FIRST AWARD. "Madam Curie." From the "Columbia Workshop" series. Plan¬
ned and produced by the Columbia Broadcasting System. Written and dir¬
ected by William N. Robson and produced with a professional cast. Broad¬
cast January 29, 1938, from 8:00 to 8:30 P.M. over Station WABC of New
York City and the CBS Network.
e. For use in school by primary children (approximately Grades I-III).
No entries.
f. For use in school by elementary children (approximately Grades IV-VI).
FIRST AWARD. "Your Health." Broadcast of January 5, 1938. Planned and
produced by the National Broadcasting Company and the American Medical
Association. Written by Russell Edgely. Directed by Gordon Hughes and
given by Dr. William H. Bauer and professional cast. Broadcast January
5, 1938, from 2:00 to 2:30 P.M. E.S.T. over Station WMAQ., Chicago, and
the NBC Red Network.
HONORABLE MENTION. "The Frog and the Butterfly." From the series "Folk
Tales of the Western World," of the American School of the Air. Planned
and produced by the Columbia Broadcasting System. Written by L. J. Mat-
schat, directed by Earle McGill and produced by professional cast. Broad¬
cast March 10, 1938, from 2:45 to 3:00 P.M. over Station WABC, New York,
and the CBS Network.
g. For use in school by .junior and/or senior high-school pupils (approximately
Grades VII-XIl).
FIRST AWARD. "Propaganda." From "Exits and Entrances" series of the
American School of the Air. Planned and produced by the Columbia Broad-
